intro: Zulustylis hygrophila, commonly known as the water grass or swamp grass, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland habitats in southern Africa. It typically grows in marshy areas, riverbanks, and other moist environments where it can thrive in saturated soil conditions. The plant has slender, grass-like leaves that are often arranged in dense tufts, and it produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are clustered in spike-like inflorescences. Zulustylis hygrophila is adapted to tolerate periodic flooding and has a fibrous root system that helps stabilize the soil in waterlogged areas. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems, supporting various forms of aquatic and terrestrial life.
